column5: and http://t.co/Z3b1LXtZ are down. And the management portal is slow to respond due to heavy traffic levels.

text: Update: http://t.co/TcOnbixe is online (with select European networks blocked). http://t.co/VAgojSHC and  http://t.co/uOzsYl9F are up.
We're very sorry for all the issues being caused by this DDOS attack!
Update: http://t.co/Z3b1LXtZ has been null routed by Linode (our ISP) in the UK. Linode has indicated an ETR of 14 hours.
SoftLayer has indicated an ETR of 12 hours.
Update: b and http://t.co/azVFCw7C have been null routed by SoftLayer (our ISP) in Dallas & Wash DC.
@neilmcquillan You're welcome. Sorry we don't have more definitive news yet.
We really apologize. We are working hard to get everything back to normal. No ETA yet.
Update: Servers in Singapore and Amsterdam are responding.All other DNS servers will be restored pending carriers lifting their null routes.
And we are working with our carrier in the UK to lift null routes they've placed to mitigate the impact of the DDOS.
Update: We now have have filters on 90% of the DNS infrastructure.
@talonsmcgee Hi
column4: we're still implementing additional filters to get this thing fully under control...no ETA yet but we're making progress.

text: @dpeservices Thank you. we are some progress...
We are now seeing reduced load after applying filters for the specific type of queries present in the DDOS.
Just letting you all know that we are still working hard to get this fixed.
